elements.name: survey_preamble_header_and_text
elements.html:
Welcome to the End-of-School-Year Survey

Code.org relies on surveys as a crucial tool to remain connected to teachers, and to give you the opportunity to provide feedback about our curriculum and your teaching experience.

This survey asks questions about your experience using Code.org in your classroom during this school year. 

Privacy and Confidentiality

  • Your individual responses here are completely confidential.
  • Your identity will never be revealed publicly or used to tie any responses back to you personally.
  • We may share de-identified, aggregate data (representing all responses) publicly.
  • Your de-identified responses will be used by Code.org, our Regional Partners, and our facilitators for program improvement.

At the end, you will be offered a $10 Amazon gift card for your time (supplies limited to first 1000 respondents).

This survey should take less than 10 minutes to complete.  Your complete honesty and candor are appreciated.

elements.name: section1_teaching_context
elements.html:
Teaching Context

This survey is about teaching with Code.org materials and resources during the 2022-23 school year.

The purpose of this survey is to understand better who our teachers are, their motivation to use the Code.org curriculum and tools, as well as some questions about professional development preferences.

Let's get started!

elements.name: teacher_role
elements.title: Which best describes you?

elements.name: teacher_role_other
elements.title: What other role best describes you?

elements.name: grade
elements.title: At what grade levels did you teach this year?

elements.name: teach_other_courses
elements.title: Are you responsible for teaching other courses or subjects at your school?
elements.description: (If so, please select all that apply)

elements.name: teach_other_courses_other
elements.title: What other courses do you teach?

elements.name: teaching_experience_years
elements.title: How many years have you been teaching at K-12 schools?
elements.description: (Please enter a number 0-90: enter 1 if this is your first year)

elements.name: teaching_experience_years_cs
elements.title: How many years have you been teaching Computer Science at the K-12 level?
elements.description: (Please enter a number 0-90: enter 0 if you don't consider yourself a Computer Science teacher; enter 1 if this is your first year)

elements.name: teaching_experience_years_cdo
elements.title: Approximately how many years have you taught using the Code.org curriculum?
elements.description: (Please enter a number 0-90: enter 1 if this is your first year)

elements.name: cdo_goal
elements.title: What is your main goal for using Code.org in your classroom?

choices.text: Teaching a full computer science course using Code.org's curriculum and activities (e.g. CS Fundamentals / CS Discoveries / CS Principles / Computer Science A)
Teaching a full computer science course using content from different providers, my own content, and some content from Code.org's curriculum and activities
Teaching some Code.org units or lessons that align to my curriculum
Exposing students to some computer science concepts through some Code.org content and activities
Providing educational activities to my students to do on their own

elements.name: cdo_goal_other
elements.title: Please describe what is your main goal for using Code.org in your classroom.

elements.name: role_as_teacher_using_cdo
elements.title: When your students are using Code.org, what is usually your role in the classroom?

choices.text: I actively teach the entire lesson
I introduce the lesson, then students go at their pace and I am a resource for them
Students engage with Code.org while I work with small groups of students on core subjects, grade, or do other classroom admin work
Students engage with Code.org as a choice during their free work time

elements.name: assigned_or_chose_to_teach
elements.title: Which of the following most closely applies to you about teaching computer science this school year?

choices.text: I was assigned to teach the course
I chose to teach the course
I don't teach a computer science course, I integrate some Code.org activities in my curriculum

elements.name: cs_content_amount
elements.title: How do you feel about the amount of computer science content you are currently teaching?

choices.text: I would like to teach more content than I currently do (e.g. additional units, additional courses)
I am teaching as much as I want to teach and my students need
I  would like to teach less content than I currently do (e.g. less units, fewer or shorter courses)

elements.name: cs_time_per_week
elements.title: On average, how many HOURS PER WEEK does a typical section of your computer science class meet?

choices.text: More than half an hour and up to one hour
More than one and up to two hours
More than two and up to three hours
More than three and up to four hours
More than four and up to five hours

elements.name: cs_plans_next_sy
elements.title: Are you planning to teach computer science next school year?

elements.name: cs_plans_next_sy_reasons_no
elements.title: Please select the main reason why you won't be teaching computer science next school year.

choices.text: I will be teaching a different subject
I am moving to a new school
Our schedule changed and computer science is no longer a course
I won't be teaching any longer

elements.name: cs_plans_next_sy_reasons_no_other
elements.title: Please describe the main reason why you won't be teaching computer science next school year.

elements.name: cs_plans_next_sy_reasons_not_sure
elements.title: Please select the reasons why you don't know if you will teach computer science next school year.

choices.text: I am moving to a new school and don't know the schedule yet
I don't know the schedule yet
I don't know yet what my plans are for next school year

elements.name: cs_plans_next_sy_reasons_not_sure_other
elements.title: Please describe the main reason why you don't know if you will teach computer science next school year.

elements.name: cdo_plans_next_sy
elements.title: Are you planning to use Code.org in your classroom next school year?

elements.name: cdo_plans_next_sy_reasons_no
elements.title: Please select the reason(s) why you don't plan to use Code.org next school year

choices.text: I have developed my own computer science materials
I no longer need to teach computer science concepts
Another computer science provider works better for my classroom
Code.org did not meet district or school requirements
Code.org's teaching tools did not meet my needs (e.g. progress tracking, feedback, grading, etc.)
My students were not engaged when using Code.org

elements.name: cdo_plans_next_sy_reasons_no_switch_provider
elements.title: What computer science provider are you planning to use next year?

elements.name: cdo_plans_next_sy_reasons_no_other
elements.title: Please describe the main reason why you don't plan to use Code.org next school year, besides the options listed.

elements.name: challenges_offer_cs
elements.title: What do you perceive to be the greatest challenges in offering computer science courses in your school?

elements.name: more_content_additional
elements.title: What additional computer science content would you want to teach?

choices.text: Computer science integrated into other subjects

elements.name: section2_description
elements.html: The questions in this section aim to understand your teaching experience with Code.org during the 2022-23 school year.

elements.name: teach_cs_cdo_easy
elements.title: How easy is it to teach computer science using code.org?

elements.name: cdo_effective
elements.title: Is teaching with Code.org effective for your students to learn computer science?

elements.name: cdo_students_engaged
elements.title: Are your students engaged when using Code.org to learn computer science?

elements.name: cdo_students_relevance
elements.title: Are the activities on Code.org relevant to your students' lives?

elements.name: cdo_students_interest
elements.title: Are the topics in Code.org's activities related to their interests?

elements.name: cdo_students_belonging
elements.title: When using Code.org, do your students feel they belong in computer science (CS)?
elements.minRateDescription: Students Don't Feel They Belong in CS
elements.maxRateDescription: Students Feel They Belong in CS

elements.name: cdo_features_intro
elements.html: In the following two questions please select the top two reasons why you opt for Code.org when choosing a computer science curriculum and tool.

elements.name: features_main_choice
elements.title: What is the most important reason why you opt for code.org?

choices.text: Code.org's curriculum affords a high-quality learning experience for my students
I have access to teacher forums when I need to troubleshoot
If I report a problem, I receive a timely response
If I submit a question or support request, I receive a timely response
It is constantly updated with new features and content
I can use code.org's curriculum resources (lesson plans, slides, examples, guides and forums) to prepare my lessons
My students have used it before so they are already familiar with it
It is recognized by other organizations as high quality (e.g. Common Sense Media, CSTA, etc.)

elements.name: features_second_choice
elements.title: What is the second most important reason why you opt for code.org?

choices.text: Code.org's curriculum affords a high-quality learning experience for my students
I have access to teacher forums when I need to troubleshoot
If I report a problem, I receive a timely response
If I submit a question or support request, I receive a timely response
It is constantly updated with new features and content
I can use code.org's curriculum resources (lesson plans, slides, examples, guides and forums) to prepare my lessons
My students have used it before so they are already familiar with it
It is recognized by other organizations as high quality (e.g. Common Sense Media, CSTA, etc.)

elements.name: section4_description
elements.html: This section of the survey includes questions about your interest in professional development courses to help us adjust our programming to better fit your needs.

elements.name: pd_interest
elements.title: Are you interested in professional development for teaching computer science?

elements.name: pd_motivation
elements.title: What is your main reason for participating in a computer science professional development?

choices.text: To get familiar with the curriculum of the course I will be teaching
To learn to do what my students will be learning and doing
To learn to use code.org's teaching and learning tools
To master the content of the course I will be teaching
To engage with fellow teachers and share experiences and best practices around teaching computer science

elements.name: pd_motivation_other
elements.title: Please describe your main reason for participating in a computer science professional development training.

elements.name: pd_type_preference
elements.title: When thinking about engaging in computer science professional development, what would would you prefer?

choices.text: A workshop experience facilitated by a CS education expert with fellow CS teachers
An online course that I can navigate at my own pace

elements.name: pd_barriers
elements.title: Which of the following might PREVENT YOU from enrolling in a professional learning workshop?

choices.text: Professional learning sessions take place after school or during weekends
Professional learning sessions take place during the summer
Professional learning sessions take place during school days
The program does not award Continued Education credit
The program that does not award certification
Time in professional learning sessions is unpaid
Attending professional learning requires scheduling around family commitments
Attending professional learning requires finding care-taking alternatives
Attending professional learning requires travel or a long commute
The program lasts more than two days
I have already participated in professional learning for Computer Science and don't need additional training

elements.name: section5_header
elements.html: Teaching Artificial Intelligence/Machine Learning and Computer Science

elements.name: section5_description
elements.html: The following are questions about your experience and interests in teaching Artificial Intelligence/Machine Learning (AI/ML). Your responses will provide insight as we develop curriculum for this content.

elements.name: ai_familiarity
elements.title: How familiar are you with AI and Machine Learning concepts and content?

elements.name: ai_teaching_experience
elements.title: Have you taught AI/ML content in a K-12 classroom?

choices.text: Yes, using mostly content from another provider
Yes, using mostly content I developed myself

elements.name: ai_teaching_interest
elements.title: Are you interested in more AI/ML content for your classroom?

choices.text: Maybe, I am not very familiar with the existing content

elements.name: ai_teaching_topics
elements.title: What topics are you most interested in having more content on?

choices.text: An overview of AI: what it is, how it works, main topics and uses
AI-generated text and images (e.g. ChatGPT, DALL-E)
AI in other subjects (e.g. ELA, history)
How AI is affecting jobs, industries and society
Computer sensing (e.g. sound and vision sensing)

elements.name: ai_teaching_topics_other
elements.title: What other topics are you interested in having more content for?

elements.name: ai_teaching_subjects
elements.title: Code.org is exploring ways to integrate AI into other subjects and topics. Out of the following subjects, which one would you want to have AI-integrated curriculum for?

elements.name: ai_teaching_subjects_other
elements.title: What other subjects would you want to have AI-integrated curriculum for?

elements.name: ai_teaching_barriers
elements.title: Which of the following do you see as the biggest barrier to implementing new AI curriculum at your school?

choices.text: I would like more preparation before introducing AI to my students
Limited time to adopt new curriculum
Lack of support from my school's administration
Lack of support from other teachers

elements.name: ai_teaching_comments
elements.title: Is there anything you would like us to know as we think about future AI/ML content development?

elements.name: teaching_background_header
elements.html:
Your Background

Lastly, we'd like to know a little bit about you and your background.

elements.name: gender
elements.title: What is your gender identity?

elements.name: race
elements.title: What is your racial or ethnic identity?

choices.text: Native Hawaiian or other Pacific Islander

elements.name: other_feedback_FR
elements.title: Is there anything else you’d like to tell us about your experience teaching {course}?

elements.name: cdo_heart_you
elements.html: Thanks from Code.org for your time, commitment and passion for teaching {course} this year.

elements.name: gift_card_conf_header
elements.html:
Amazon Gift Card Confirmation

Please accept a small token of appreciation in the form of an Amazon gift card, while supplies last.*

*First 1000 respondents will receive gift card. Please allow 1-2 weeks to receive the code.

elements.name: permission
elements.title: I give Code.org permission to quote my written feedback from today for use on social media, promotional materials, and other communications.

choices.text: Yes, I give permission to quote me and use my name.
Yes, I give permission to quote me, but I want to be anonymous.
No, I do not give permission to quote me.
